1.title: What is Apologetics?
1.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

2.title: What is Truth?
2.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

3.title: Truth Bearing Statements
3.plot: Not all statements are capable of being "true" or "false." Ken Coughlan explains what makes something a "truth bearing statement."

4.title: The Law of Non-Contradiction
4.plot: Perhaps the most fundamental rule of logic that supports not just all Christian apologetics, but all of reasoning itself, is the law of non-contradiction, one that is increasingly under attack from New Age and Eastern philosophies.

5.title: Subjective vs Objective Truth
5.plot: Some truths are "subjective" and others are "objective." The truths of Christianity claim to be objective. Apologist Ken Coughlan defines the difference between the two.

6.title: Does Truth Exist?
6.plot: In today's postmodern culture, many people try to deny that objective truth even exists. Something may be "true for you but not true for me." Ken Coughlan responds to that position.

7.title: How Do Arguments Work?
7.plot: Before evaluating whether arguments are any good, we need to know how they work. Ken discusses the difference between a valid argument and a sound one.

8.title: Introducing the Kalam Argument
8.plot: Ken Coughlan starts demonstrating the existence of God by introducing the Kalam Cosmological Argument.

9.title: Does Beginning to Exist Require a Cause?
9.plot: Premise 1 of the Kalam Cosmological arguments says "Whatever begins to exist has a cause." But is this premise true? This is the start to an answer for that question.

10.title: Formal and Informal Fallacies
10.plot: Premise 1 of the Kalam Cosmological argument says "Whatever begins to exist has a cause." Some skeptics try to deny this premise by claiming it commits the "fallacy of composition." The response to this objection begins by understanding the difference between formal and informal fallacies.

11.title: Does Kalam Commit the Fallacy of Composition?
11.plot: One common objection to the kalam cosmological argument for the existence of God is that it allegedly commits the "fallacy of composition." What is that fallacy and how you can determine when it applies and when it doesn't? Does the kalam argument really violate it?

12.title: Is "Zero Energy" Really "Nothing?"
12.plot: Physicist Paul Davies disagrees with the kalam cosmological argument for the existence of God because he claims matter can spontaneously pop into existence out of nothing in a state of "zero energy." But this terminology is very misleading. Ken explains why.

13.title: Does Quantum Physics Show Uncaused Creation?: Part 1
13.plot: Some people claim that quantum physics shows things popping into existence without a cause, therefore disproving premise 1 of the Kalam Cosmological Argument for the existence of God. But is this really true? Part 1 of a response discusses the difference between "unpredictable" and "uncaused."

14.title: Does Quantum Physics Show Uncaused Creation?: Part 2
14.plot: Some people object to the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God, claiming that at the quantum level virtual particles pop into existence, uncaused, out of "nothing." If virtual particles can do it, why not the universe as a whole? However, this objection doesn't hold up.

15.title: Did the Universe Begin to Exist?
15.plot: Premise 2 of the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God says that the universe began to exist. Here is one simple way to know this premise is true.

16.title: Are Actual Infinities Possible?
16.plot: Premise 2 of the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God says that the universe began to exist. In order for this to be false, it must be possible for there to have been an infinite amount of time in the past. Ken provides a few examples to argue that this type of actual infinity cannot exist in the real, physical world.

17.title: The 2nd Law of Thermodynamics & the Origin of the Universe
17.plot: Premise 2 of the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God says that the universe began to exist. The second law of thermodynamics gives us another reason to accept this premise as true.

18.title: The Big Bang and the Beginning of the Universe
18.plot: Most modern cosmologists believe the universe began with a Big Bang. Ken gives a brief, easy to understand overview of the evidence and its implications for the Kalam Cosmological Argument for the existence of God.

19.title: Did Stephen Hawking Disprove the Big Bang?
19.plot: Premise 2 of the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God says that the universe began to exist. In his book "A Brief History of Time," however, Stephen Hawking proposed a model for the origin of the universe that he claimed would avoid the need for a beginning. Ken evaluates whether his model was successful.

20.title: Has the Universe Been Oscillating Since Eternity?
20.plot: Premise 2 of the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God says that the universe began to exist. But oscillating universe theories claim the universe never had a beginning. Instead, it expands, contracts, then bounces back and expands again, allegedly since eternity past. Ken explores whether the evidence support this type of theory.

21.title: Do Vacuum Fluctuations Prove the Universe is Eternal?
21.plot: Premise 2 of the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God says that the universe began to exist. Vacuum fluctuation models agree that out particular universe had a beginning, but claim it is only one of many universes in an eternal primordial vacuum. These models, though, have a serious logical problem inherent in them.

22.title: Does Chaotic Inflation Mean There Was No Beginning?
22.plot: Premise 2 of the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God says that the universe began to exist. Andrei Linde proposed the chaotic inflation model and the concept of an eternal multiverse, but his model wound up requiring a singularity anyway, so it did not change the need for a beginning point.

23.title: Does Steinhardt's Cyclic Model Show the Universe is Past Eternal?
23.plot: Premise 2 of the Kalam Cosmological argument for the existence of God says that the universe began to exist. Paul Steinhardt has proposed a model based on String Theory that he believes allows the universe to be eternal in the past. Ken discusses some of the issues with this model.

imdb.title: Pocket Sized Apologetics
plot: In 2 minutes or less each week, we walk through the evidence God has placed in the world to demonstrate the truth of Christianity.::Ken Coughlan
